myQuestion.label: Are you now covered by any form of health insurance or health plan or do you not have health insurance at this time?

Which of the following is your MAIN source of health insurance coverage? Is it a plan through your employer, a plan through your spouse’s employer, a plan you purchased yourself, are you covered by Medicare or Medicaid, some other government program, or do you get your health insurance from somewhere else? <small class='muted'>Base: Covered by health insurance</small>
Within the last twelve months, have you or a member of your family put off any sort of medical treatment because of the cost you would have to pay?

There’s been a lot of debate over the Affordable Care Act, sometimes called Obamacare, which seeks to provide more people with health insurance. Do you feel that you have a good understanding of how the Affordable Care Act will affect you and your family, or are you not very clear on how it will affect you and your family?
Given what you know about the law, do you have a generally favorable or generally unfavorable opinion of it?
Overall, what do you think is the best approach to the health care law at this point?

Response.Label: Let it stand as it is
Wait and see before deciding what should be done

myQuestion.label: Starting Jan. 1, 2014, most Americans above a certain income level will be required by the Affordable Care Act to purchase health insurance or pay a fine. The government would provide subsidies for individuals earning less than $46,000 a year or a family of four earning less than $94,200. Do you support or oppose this requirement?

Part of this law would expand Medicaid to provide coverage to many low-income adults currently without coverage, such as single adults earning below $16,000 a year. The federal government would initially cover 100 percent of the entire cost of this expansion for the first few years. After that, the federal government would pay 90 percent, with the states paying 10 percent. States have the right to refuse the expansion, and Georgia has decided against it, citing the cost. Do you think that Georgia SHOULD allow the expansion of Medicaid to cover low income uninsured adults, or should it refuse to participate?

Response.Label: No, Georgia should refuse to participate

myQuestion.label: allowing children to stay on their parents’ insurance plans until they turn 26
prohibiting health insurance companies from charging women higher premiums than men
limiting the amount health insurance companies can charge older people
requiring health insurance companies to provide insurance to anyone who applies, regardless of pre-existing conditions
requiring insurance companies to cover birth control pills and contraceptive devices
